question: Question_08_(b)
statement:
Consider the chemical reaction

\[\displaystyle
A + B \rightarrow C + D.\]

Suppose at time \emph{t} = 0 sec the concentration of chemical \emph{A}
is 0.1 mol/L, the concentration of chemical \emph{B} is 0.2 mol/L, and
the concentrations of chemicals \emph{C} and \emph{D} are both 0. For
\emph{t} $\geq$ 0, let \emph{x(t)} be the concentration of chemical
\emph{D} in mol/L. It can be shown that \emph{x(t)} is the solution to
the initial-value problem

\[\frac{dx}{dt} = k(0.1-x)(0.2-x), \quad x(0)=0,\]

where \emph{k} is a positive constant whole value can be determined by
experiment.

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
(b) What value does the concentration of chemical \emph{D} approach as
\emph{t} approaches $\infty$?
\end{description}
sols:
From the previous part, we know that

$\displaystyle x(t) = \frac{0.2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}} -0.2 }{2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}} - 1}$

taking the limit as \emph{t} tends to infinity yields

$\lim_{t \to \infty} \frac{0.2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}} -0.2 }{2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}} - 1} = \lim_{t \to \infty} \frac{0.2 -0.2e^{\tfrac{-kt}{10}} }{2 - e^{\tfrac{-kt}{10}}} = \frac{0.2}{2} = \frac{1}{10}$

Thus, the concentration tends to $\tfrac{1}{10} = 0.1$ as \emph{t} tends
to infinity.
hints:
Use the previous part to get the equation. Then take the limit. You may
want to factor out a $e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}}$ from the numerator and
denominator.
